Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Multi-Sensory Therapy Program for Children with Autism Spectrum Disorder
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will develop a multi-sensory therapy program for children diagnosed with Autism Spectrum Disorder by improving eye contact. Children with Autism Spectrum Disorder do not make eye contact readily and eye contact is a key component in progressing social behavior. Current methodologies to assist these children in maximizing their capabilities are out of reach for many, costing families thousands of dollars a month, requiring 25-40 hours per week and offer measureable improvements at less than 47%. This project has shown positive results in preliminary testing and is expected to result in an affordable, practical solution to the challenges children with Autism Spectrum Disorder and their families encounter. As their social skills improve, children with Autism Spectrum Disorder will be able to build and maintain friendships, become more fully engaged in society, prepare them to become self-sustaining adults, and increase their employment opportunities. Additionally, this program can also be expanded to children with other disabilities or children without disabilities, resulting in increased ability to also build and maintain friendships, become more fully engaged in society to prepare them to become self-sustaining adults, and increase their employment opportunities. Potential customers will include parents, school districts, and other professional and nonprofessional caregivers. The high need for this program will create market growth, creating new jobs and generating tax revenue.

The goal for this project is to develop a multi-sensory program, developed for smart mobile devices, that improves children with Autism Spectrum Disorder?s social skills so they can function as their typical peers who do not have Autism Spectrum Disorder. This goal is accomplished by developing an interactive program that teaches the social skill, making eye contact with individuals the child does and does not know, by improving sensory integration and regulating the overactive amygdala. Funding would allow for the development of the program to test, measure and quantify sensory integration and eye contact improvement for children with Autism Spectrum Disorder. Analyses will reflect the interpretation requirements of a Pre vs. Post, Intervention versus Control design. All statistical analyses and tests will be conducted using the widely used program Statistical Package for the Social Sciences version 17 or higher and will be verified with Statistical Analysis System when appropriate or marginal findings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is one of the fastest growing developmental disabilities in the US with 1 in 59 born with autism. Teaching It Right’s goal is to help improve the lives of children with autism by developing a patent pending multi-sensory social skill program. The first module in the program is making eye contact.

During Teaching It Right’s customer discovery, Teaching It Right’s team interviewed over 100 parents, teachers, and therapists that are directly involved with the ASD population. The desire to have a program to improve the social skills of a child with ASD was expressed by all who were interviewed. The need for a child with ASD to improve their eye contact with another individual while communicating with him/her was among the top three specific social skills that was claimed most important during those interviews.

Prior to Phase I research, Teaching It Right developed a prototype to help children with ASD increase eye contact with people the child knows such as a parent or teacher. In the Phase I research, Teaching It Right developed a prototype to help children with ASD increase eye contact with a “Safe Stranger.” “Safe Strangers” is defined as a safe individual that the child does not know but someone the child would typically interact with in any given day. An example of these “Safe Strangers” would be a new peer at school or a community worker, such as someone who works at the grocery store. The Teaching It Right team felt it was crucial to develop a program that helps the students generalize social skills with community members to help them integrate into society and prepare them for the workforce.

Additionally, Teaching It Right’s program also works to improve the child’s sensory integration while also reinforcing the social skills. The lack of sensory integration is prominent in children with ASD, adversely affecting the child’s functional and social abilities. This can often result in a child becoming “overstimulated” in an environment. When a child is overstimulated, it is difficult for him/her to: interact with another person, sit in a classroom, participate in daily activities such as grocery shopping or going to a restaurant with their family. Overstimulation is difficult on the child and affects the caretakers, teachers, and family at a high level. Teaching It Right believes that in order to improve the student’s social skills, sensory integration needs to be addressed.

Teaching It Right tested the program with 45 children in a Control vs Intervention design. Results showed that children in the intervention group made improvement with their eye contact and sensory integration and the children in the control group did not show improvement. For example, eye contact duration was measured given a 2-minute time period with a “Safe Stranger.” Pretest results show that children in the intervention group average mean was 8.7% and children in the control group average mean was 8.5%. Children in the intervention group then received Teaching It Right’s intervention while children in the control group received their regular special education classes. Post results show that children in the intervention group average mean increased to 47.1%. Children in the control group average mean decreased to 7.2%. Teaching It Right also interviewed parents with children in the intervention group to determine what improvements they noticed with their child. Parent feedback involved noticing their child had: increased eye contact, increased self-esteem, increased communication skills, increased desire to want to socialize and increased sensory integration.

Teaching It Right is pleased with the results of this study and is confident that this program will be effective for individuals with autism. Those who received the most consistent intervention excelled. Improvement in eye contact and sensory integration is an essential skill to building relationships. It is an important building block to laying a strong foundation for introducing additional social skills and empowering these children for future success.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 06/29/2018
Modified by: Andrea F Johnson
